text: im giving 5 stars to help offset the ridiculous bad reviews people give this. I hope nobody pays attention to the loser critics. This was an overall good movie, and a new take on the robot vs human dynamic that everyone has been thinking about for the past 20 years. It's a unique, fresh story and it deserves way better reviews. I didnt expect much going in to be honest, but I just finished it with my 10 year old son and we both enjoyed it very much.

Most reviewers seem to fault this movie for straying from the book.  Not having read it, I can't criticize based on that.  On it's own, it's intriguing and enjoyable -- the visuals, especially the robots (inventive design and motion-capture), are excellent.  The cast is top-notch, the dialogue is sharp and humorous enough times to hold attention.  Perhaps the pace drags a bit, but I didn't notice -- I wanted to see what happened next.  And Woody Norman, the young man who plays Millie Bobby Brown's brother, is outstanding in a cast that has Stanley Tucci and Giancarlo Esposito as the bad guys, Chris Pratt and Anthony Mackie as the good, and Woody Harrelson as Mr. Peanut
Such a great and emotional movie. Loved it so much and I’m so glad I watched it

Loved it! I was sceptical at the beginning but the story as a whole is fun and nostalgic. Yes, there's a lot of recycled material (mostly star wars) but it's done well and doesn't try to hide it. I will read the book as that seems to be the core of the discontent. I agree with the critiques but it is still very enjoyable, especially during the holidays. Hopeful and not too heavy. Thank you Russo brothers.

The Electric State dazzles with striking visuals, and having Chris Pratt in the cast adds a welcome spark that helps make the film more enjoyable. The robots’ personalities steal nearly every scene they’re in, and the story is surprisingly easy to follow as its world unfolds. Unfortunately, the ending lands with a thud, Millie Bobby Brown’s performance never quite clicks, and the overall execution feels a bit thin, the kind of narrative that might have worked better as a longer series with more room for character and story development. Still, despite its flaws, it’s worth a watch as long as you keep expectations in check.

It felt like the movie was rushed into completion, as if the directors had an incredible amount to express but not enough time to fully bring their vision to life. The story had so much depth and potential that it could have easily been expanded into a trilogy or even a saga. With more time, the world and its characters could have been explored in ways that made the emotional and thematic moments hit even harder. Despite that, I truly loved the film. It’s creative, powerful, and full of heart. I just wish more movies like this would come along to capture that same kind of magic.
